title.narrative: Make Way Kenya - Liliane Fonds

description.narrative:
Make Way - embracing intersectionality for health equity & justice.
The Make Way programme (2021-2025) aims to ensure youth in all their diversity can fully realise their sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR). We promote an intersectional approach to addressing SRHR issues. This means making overlapping vulnerabilities visible to understand their effects on people’s SRHR.
We develop innovative tools and build capacities of other civil society organisations to advocate the needed policy and societal changes.
Our partnership consists of Akina Mama wa Afrika, The Circle of Concerned African Women Theologians, Kenya, Forum for African Women Educationalists, Liliane Foundation, VSO Netherlands, and Wemos, and we work in partnership with the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
We implement Make Way in Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda, Zambia, the Eastern and Southern African region and at the global level.
Make Way Kenya context - Liliane Fonds
Actual expenses of LF in Kenya in 2021
Amount that LF commits for Make Way Kenya, 5 years.

title.narrative: Project photo
MT SO 1: The Kenya CCG, the Make Way collaborating partners, Make Way CSO allies and the youth panel are actively engaging in intersectional SRHR budget advocacy

description.narrative: With 'active engagement' we mean: Engaging based on knowledge of budget analysis skills and monitoring the budget for SRH

title.narrative: MT SO 1.1.a: # of advocacy initiatives (national level) - by the consortium partners, collaborating partners, CSO allies and youth panel - aimed at improving (intersectional) SRHR budgets

description.narrative:
Count the number of advocacy initiatives organised by consortium partners, collaborating partners, CSO allies and youth panel with the aim of improving intersectional SRHR budgets.
​
Count 3 x Unique - (target, MT actual, ET actual). Count national level initiatives.
​
Advocacy initiatives: Actions that speak for, or favour, the improvement of intersectional SRHR budgets. These include, but are not limited to: social & media campaigns, public campaigns, peaceful protests, picketing, meeting with duty bearers, community sensitisation.
Improved: funds and resources allocation for intersectional SRHR should increase.
Budgets: SRHR-related county and national budgets.
​
Links with: SCS041 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

comment.narrative: Reporting 3 Times Unique (target for the full programme; actual MTR and actual End of Programme)
Other consortium partner organisations have targets and will report on actuals for this indicator.

title.narrative: ST SO 3: The Kenya CCG, the Make Way collaborating partners and the youth panel understand and practice key concepts of meaningful youth participation

description.narrative: With 'meaningful youth participation' we mean: Youth are involved in the design, planning, implementation, monitoring, decision-making and learning of the programme.

title.narrative: ST SO 3.2.a: # of times consortium partners, Make Way collaborating partners and the youth panel participate in Meaningful Youth Participation (MYP) forums/meetings (at national or international level)

description.narrative:
Count the number of MYP meetings attended by either consortium partners, collaborating partners, and/or youth panelist.
​
Count unique values (counting only once) at mid-term and end-term.
​
MYP Forums/meetings: External physical or virtual platforms, avenues, and discussions in for open discussions on intersectional SRHR issues that engage youth in a meaningful way.
​
Links with: SCS031 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at national and international level

comment.narrative: Reporting 3 Times Unique (target for the full programme; actual MTR and actual End of Programme).

title.narrative: LT SO 3: Donors, influencers, media and other CSO actors increasingly engage and support intersectional SRHR

LT SO 3.1.a: # of times Make Way consortium partners, collaborating partners and/or CSO allies are present and on the agenda with their issues, of the meetings of donors and other key stakeholders ((inter)national level)

description.narrative:
Count number of times, unique values (counting only once) at mid-term and end-term.
Count number of times present and on the agenda with our issues, during meetings at (inter)national level.
​
Donors: People or organisations supporting intersectional SRHR through providing technical and financial support.
Influencers: People who will inspire or influence other people to embrace intersectional SRHR (religious leaders, teachers, village elders, youth leaders, community Health Volunteers, mainstream Media, social media)
Key Stakeholders: Ministry of Health, Ministry of Education, CEC Education, CEC Health, Ministry of Gender, County department of Gender and Social Services, Health workers)
Sub-national: CEC (This needs to be written in full) Health, CEC Education, County department of gender and social services.
National; Ministry of Health, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Gender, National Gender and Equality Commission (NGEC), DPP, Court Users Committee, Directorate of Criminal Investigations
​
Links with:
SCS031 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at national and international level

comment.narrative: Reporting 3 Times Unique (target for the full programme; actual MTR and actual End of Programme).

Other consortium partner organisations have targets and will report on actuals for this indicator.
Reporting 3 Times Unique (target for the full programme; actual MTR and actual End of Programme).

title.narrative: LT SO 2: Duty-bearers at different levels use data on intersectional SRHR to inform decision-making on SRHR policies and programmes
LT SO 2.1.b: # of meetings (at sub-national level) during which evidence based data is used to inform the decision making process on intersectional SRH

description.narrative:
Count meetings, unique values (counting only once) at mid-term and end-term.
Count meetings held at sub-national level.
​
Meetings: any type of meeting where policy/programmes/laws are being discussed and being formed by duty bearers
Evidence-based data: Qualitative and quantitative data gathered based on stakeholder’s voices and using structured tools and/or research (e.g., social accountability tools)
Informed decision making: data gathered above is collected, analysed and disseminated in a participatory process to guide decisions around SRHR policies, guidelines, implementation
​
Links with:
SCS032 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at sub-national level

comment.narrative: Reporting 3 Times Unique (target for the full programme; actual MTR and actual End of Programme).

title.narrative: ST SO 2: The Kenya CCG, the Make Way collaborating partners and the youth panel have the capacity, knowledge and skills on intersectional SRHR lobby and advocacy.
ST SO 2.1.b: # of consortium partners, Make Way collaborating partners and youth panels (not youth or women led) trained on intersectional SRHR lobby and advocacy.

description.narrative:
Count the number of consortium partners, MW CPs and youth panels that are trained on intersectional SRHR lobby and advocacy. Note: do not count the individual participants but count the number of organisations.
Count the number of CSOs that are not youth or women led. Count unique values (counting only once).
​
Links with: SRH023 - # of CSOs (not youth or women led) with increased L&A capacities

title.narrative: ST SO 2.1.a: # of consortium partners, Make Way collaborating partners and youth panels (youth-led) trained on intersectional SRHR lobby and advocacy.

description.narrative:
Count the number of consortium partners, MW CPs and youth panels that are trained on intersectional SRHR lobby and advocacy. Note: do not count the individual participants but count the number of organisations.
​
Count the number of CSOs that are youth-led. Count unique values (counting only once).
​
Links with:
**SRH022 - # of youth led CSOs with increased L&A capacities**

title.narrative: MT SO 3: The Kenya CCG, the Make Way collaborating partners, Make Way CSO allies and the youth panel are actively engaging in lobby and advocacy for strengthening health care workers' capacity on intersectionality to increase AAAQ of SRH services
MT SO 3.1.b: # of joint advocacy initiatives (sub-national level) targeting health care workers capacity strengthening on intersectionality to increase AAAQ of SRH services

description.narrative:
Count the number of joint advocacy initiatives that target the strengthening of health workers' capacity on intersectionality to increase AAAQ of SRH services.
Count 3 x Unique - (target, MT actual, ET actual). Count sub-national level initiatives.
​
Joint: Activities carried out in collaboration with key stakeholders including, Make Way CPs, Make Way consortium partners, Make Way youth panel, CSOs allies, and other civil society actors.
Health care workers: Health care workers working within the SRH scope in the context of Kenya. These include, but are not limited to: community health volunteers, medical practitioners, nurses, clinical officers, public health officer, pharmacists.
AAAQ:
Availability: Existence of services;
Accessibility: Physical, financial and administrative;
Acceptability: respectful of culture of individuals, minorities and communities as well as change of attitude;
Quality: service providers possess necessary skills and training.
Capacity strengthening on intersectionality includes training; skills and knowledge development; mentorshipping, coaching, benchmarking initiatives; Value Clarification and attitude transformation (VCAT); sensitization.
​
Links with: SCS042 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency at sub-national level

comment.narrative: Reporting 3 Times Unique (target for the full programme; actual MTR and actual End of Programme).
